subs.text: @nealjennings I still have my licence, but only ever use it for ID. There’s maybe one or two places I want to go to that only a car can take me to, but so what? If I had a partner, maybe things would be different, but otherwise, my feet, bikes, trains, and buses get me where I need to go.

subs.text: I managed to sell the ticket, for less than I would have thorough an online service, but for more than a scalper was going to give me. And, apparently, I broke the terms of the market service I sold it on. That was unnecessarily stressful.
subs.rawText: I managed to sell the ticket, for less than I would have thorough an online service, but for more than a scalper was going to give me. And, apparently, I broke the terms of the market service I sold it on. That was unnecessarily stressful.

subs.text: One thing I learned from this whole process: A screenshot of a QR code that someone texts to you is not a valid ticket. Only the “original” QR code is. Huh?
subs.rawText: One thing I learned from this whole process: A screenshot of a QR code that someone texts to you is not a valid ticket. Only the “original” QR code is. Huh?

subs.text: Good thing I had to presence of mind to stay there right next to the guy who bought my ticket as he went in, so I showed the gate attendant my web-based version, i.e. literally the same QR code.
subs.rawText: Good thing I had to presence of mind to stay there right next to the guy who bought my ticket as he went in, so I showed the gate attendant my web-based version, i.e. literally the same QR code.

subs.text: He went in before me, which was smart, so that he wouldn’t be stuck outside if something went wrong. And something did go wrong, which we figured out on the fly.
subs.rawText: He went in before me, which was smart, so that he wouldn’t be stuck outside if something went wrong. And something did go wrong, which we figured out on the fly.

subs.text: Also, I bought what I thought was a will call ticket but Scotiabank Arena doesn’t give out paper tickets. It was ultimately emailed (actually texted, because email didn’t work). So, also, huh?
subs.rawText: Also, I bought what I thought was a will call ticket but Scotiabank Arena doesn’t give out paper tickets. It was ultimately emailed (actually texted, because email didn’t work). So, also, huh?

subs.text: The whole thing worked out in the end, so I’ll sleep easy, but was so awkward at multiple points.

subs.text: You know what’s irritating? News anchors talking over the first few words of a speech they are about to cover. You know what they could do instead, and very few people would care? Delay the feed of the speech ever so slightly so that we get to hear everything.
subs.rawText: You know what’s irritating? News anchors talking over the first few words of a speech they are about to cover. You know what they could do instead, and very few people would care? Delay the feed of the speech ever so slightly so that we get to hear everything.

subs.text: Sports broadcasts do it all the time, not so much for speeches or news conferences, but for the live events they cover, and it’s so fluid that hardly anybody notices.
subs.rawText: Sports broadcasts do it all the time, not so much for speeches or news conferences, but for the live events they cover, and it’s so fluid that hardly anybody notices.

subs.text: The next time you watch a baseball game on TV, notice how, when the broadcasts show a pitcher up close, they very slightly rewind the action once the pitch is actually made.
